named-value.description: Some properties accept arbitrary author-defined identifiers as a component value. This generic data type is denoted by <custom-ident>, and represents any valid CSS identifier that does not otherwise appear as a pre-defined keyword in that property's value definition. Such identifiers are fully case-sensitive, even in the ASCII range (e.g. ‘example’ and ‘EXAMPLE’ are two different, unrelated user-defined identifiers).

property.percentage: refers to width of the line box
width and height of border box

property.applies: non-replaced block-level elements (except table elements), table cells, and inline-block elements
non-replaced block-level elements (except table elements), table cells, and inline-block elements
block-level elements, except floating and absolutely positioned elements
non-replaced block-level elements (except table elements), table cells, and inline-block elements

property.description: The touch-action CSS property determines whether touch input may trigger default behavior supplied by user agent. This includes, but is not limited to, behaviors such as panning or zooming.

name.tooltip: The user agent may determine any permitted touch behaviors, such as panning and zooming manipulations of the viewport, for touches that begin on the element.
Touches that begin on the element must not trigger default touch behaviors.
The user agent may consider touches that begin on the element only for the purposes of horizontally scrolling the element's nearest ancestor with horizontally scrollable content.
The user agent may consider touches that begin on the element only for the purposes of vertically scrolling the element's nearest ancestor with vertically scrollable content.

property.tooltip: Specifies whether to use native-style scrolling in an overflow:scroll element.

name.tooltip: Native-style scrolling. Specifying this style has the effect of creating a staking context (like opacity, masks, and transforms).

pseudo-class.tooltip: The :root pseudo-class represents an element that is the root of the document. In HTML 4, this is always the HTML element.
The :last-child pseudo-class represents an element that is the last child of some other element.
pseudo-class.description:
Same as :(1).

The :last-child pseudo-class represents an element that is the last child of some other element.


The following selector represents a list item li that is the last child of an ordered list ol.


ol > li:last-child

pseudo-class.tooltip: The :first-of-type pseudo-class represents an element that is the first sibling of its type in the list of children of its parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
Same as :(1).

The :first-of-type pseudo-class represents an element that is the first sibling of its type in the list of children of its parent element.

pseudo-class.tooltip: The :last-of-type pseudo-class represents an element that is the last sibling of its type in the list of children of its parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
Same as :(1).

The :last-of-type pseudo-class represents an element that is the last sibling of its type in the list of children of its parent element.


The following selector represents the last data cell td of a table row tr.


tr > td:last-of-type.

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents an element that has a parent element and whose parent element has no other element children.
pseudo-class.description:
Represents an element that has a parent element and whose parent element has no other element children.


Same as :: or :(1):(1), but with a lower specificity.

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents an element that has a parent element and whose parent element has no other element children with the same expanded element name.
pseudo-class.description:
Represents an element that has a parent element and whose parent element has no other element children with the same expanded element name.


Same as :: or :(1):(1), but with a lower specificity.

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents an element that has no children at all.
pseudo-class.description:
The :empty pseudo-class represents an element that has no children at all.

In terms of the document tree, only element nodes and content nodes whose data has a non-zero length must be considered as affecting emptiness; comments, processing instructions, and other nodes must not affect whether an element is considered empty or not.


p:empty is a valid representation of the following fragment:

<p></p>

foo:empty is not a valid representation for the following fragments:

<foo>bar</foo>
<foo><bar>bla</bar></foo>
<foo>this is not <bar>:empty</bar></foo>

The :target pseudo-class selects the target element of the referring URI. A fragment identifier is used to identify a location within a document, and is formed using a number sign followed by an anchor identifier—for example, http://www.example.com/mypage.html#section_3.

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents user interface elements that are in an enabled state.
pseudo-class.description: The :enabled pseudo-class is a UI element states pseudo-class. UI element states pseudo-classes select UI elements (form controls such as radio buttons or check boxes) that are in a certain state—enabled, disabled, or selected (checked).

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents user interface elements that are in an disabled state.
pseudo-class.description: The :disabled pseudo-class is a UI element states pseudo-class. UI element states pseudo-classes select UI elements (form controls such as radio buttons or check boxes) that are in a certain state—enabled, disabled, or selected (checked).

pseudo-class.tooltip: Represents toggable elements (e.g. radio buttons or checkboxes) that are toggled on.

pseudo-class.description:
Radio and checkbox elements can be toggled by the user, but are sometimes in an indeterminate state, neither checked nor unchecked. This can be due to an element attribute, or DOM manipulation.

A future version of CSS3-selectors specification may introduce an :indeterminate pseudo-class that applies to such elements.
The :fullscreen pseudo-class must match the top element of the document's fullscreen element stack (if any).

pseudo-element.tooltip: The ::first-letter pseudo-element selects the first letter of the first line of a block.
pseudo-element.description: The ::first-letter pseudo-element must select the first letter of the first line of a block, if it is not preceded by any other content (such as images or inline tables) on its line.

pseudo-element.tooltip: The :first-line pseudo-element applies special styles to the contents of the first formatted line of a paragraph.
pseudo-element.description: The ::first-line pseudo-element applies special styles to the contents of the first formatted line of a paragraph.

pseudo-element.tooltip: The ::before pseudo-element specifies the location of content before an element in the document tree.
The ::after pseudo-element specifies the location of content after an element in the document tree.
Applies rules to the portion of a document that has been highlighted (e.g., selected with the mouse or another pointing device) by the user.

pseudo-element.description: Each element in the top layer's stack has a ::backdrop pseudo-element. This pseudo-element is a box rendered immediately below the element (and above the element below the element in the stack, if any), within the same top layer. The ::backdrop pseudo-element can be used to create a backdrop that hides the underlying document for an element in the top layer's stack. E.g. for the element that is displayed fullscreen as described by this specification. It does not inherit from any element and is not inherited from. No restrictions are made on what properties apply to this pseudo-element either.

pseudo-class.tooltip: Matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings before it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
The :nth-child CSS pseudo-class matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings before it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.

This can more clearly be described this way: the matching element is the bth child of an element after all its children have been split into groups of a elements each.

Syntax

element:nth-child(an + b) {}

pseudo-class.tooltip: Matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings after it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
The :nth-last-child CSS pseudo-class matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings after it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.

See : for a more thorough description of the syntax of its argument.

Syntax

element:nth-last-child(an + b) {}

pseudo-class.tooltip: Matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same element name before it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
The :nth-of-type CSS pseudo-class matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same element name before it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.

See : for a more thorough description of the syntax of its argument.

Syntax

element:nth-of-type(an + b) {}

pseudo-class.tooltip: Matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same element name after it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.
pseudo-class.description:
The :nth-last-of-type CSS pseudo-class matches an element that has an+b-1 siblings with the same element name after it in the document tree, for a given positive or zero value for n, and has a parent element.

See : for a more thorough description of the syntax of its argument.

Syntax

element:nth-last-of-type(an + b) {}

pseudo-class.tooltip: Matches an element that is not represented by the argument.
pseudo-class.description: The negation pseudo-class, :not(X), is a functional notation taking a simple selector X as an argument. It matches an element that is not represented by the argument. X must not contain another negation selector, or any pseudo-elements.

function.tooltip: Enables display of stylistic alternates (font specific, OpenType feature: salt <feature-value-name>).
Enables display with stylistic sets (font specific, OpenType feature: ss<feature-index> OpenType currently defines ss01 through ss20).
Enables display of specific character variants (font specific, OpenType feature: cv<feature-index> OpenType currently defines cv01 through cv99).
Enables display of swash glyphs (font specific, OpenType feature: swsh <feature-index>, cswh <feature-index>).
Enables replacement of default glyphs with ornaments, if provided in the font (font specific, OpenType feature: ornm <feature-index>).
Enables display of alternate annotation forms (font specific, OpenType feature: nalt <feature-index>).

name.tooltip: The value is a CSS <color> value. The default is UA dependent but must be the same as the initial value of the 'color' property.
The value is the contents of a CSS string. The default is the empty string.

The value is the URI part of a 'url()' expression. The default is a UA-dependent URI defined to point to a non-existent document with a generic error condition. (i.e. it shouldn't be an FTP URI that causes a DNS error, or an HTTP URI that results in a 404, it should be a non-descript error condition.)
The value is a CSS integer. The default is 0. The default should also be used if the property in question only accepts integers within a certain range and the attribute is out of range.
The value is a CSS number. The default is 0.0. The default should also be used if the property in question only accepts numbers within a certain range and the attribute is out of range.
The value is a CSS length, and the unit identifier (if any) will appear in the attribute value. The default is 0.
The value is a CSS angle, and the unit identifier (if any) will appear in the attribute value. The default is 0.
The value is a CSS time, and the unit identifier (if any) will appear in the attribute value. The default is 0.
The value is a CSS frequency, and the unit identifier (if any) will appear in the attribute value. The default is 0.
